awd_titl_txt: Bringing Computer Science to High Schools in Rural Appalachia
awd_abstract_narration:
Appalachian State University (AppState), partnering with the Friday Institute of Educational Innovation at North Carolina State, proposes a project -- CS4App: Bringing Computer Science to High Schools in Rural Appalachia -- to expand and diversify Computer Science (CS) education in rural high schools. The project will gain insight into the obstacles to CS education faced by high school students living regions such as Appalachia with high rates of poverty, and it will develop a comprehensive program to prepare and support their teachers in teaching an AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) course.

CS4App will develop a Networked Improvement Community (NIC) partnering AppState faculty and regional teachers with an interest in offering CSP at their school. The Friday Institute will deliver an effective blend of research-based teacher professional development (PD) including a 4-week, intensive training in the summer and continued interactions during the school year. The PD will introduce CS technical and pedagogical content, as well as leadership development, inquiry-based instruction, and student equity issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Computer Science faculty from Appalachian State University (App State) established a two-year, small CS4All high school strand project named CS4App: Bringing Computer Science to High Schools in Rural Appalachia, funded by the National Science Foundation. Program faculty have partnered with seven counties in North Carolina, Virginia, and Tennessee to train high school teachers to teach the Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (APCSP) course. The population targeted by this program includes students living in rural areas with high rates of poverty and the teachers that serve those communities.

The goals of the CS4App program were to:

  1. Establish a Networked Improvement Community (NIC) partnering App State faculty and regional teachers interested in offering an AP Computer Science Principles (APCSP) course at their school.
  2. Gain insight into the obstacles to computer science (CS) education faced by the target population.
  3. Develop a comprehensive program to prepare and support high school teachers to teach the APCSP course.

Eleven and nine high school teachers from North Carolina schools were accepted into the CS4App program for the 2022-2023 and 2021-2022 programs, respectively. These teachers participated in a summer program that included a week long code.org training. Also, all teachers participated in four Saturday code.org training workshops. In addition, two teachers, one from our 2015-2017 RET program and another from our first cohort were selected to serve as coaches and work with the teachers during summer program in Year 1 and year 2, respectively.      

Summer Training Programs:

During summer program, participants attended daily workshops and a Wednesday night speaker session each week. Week 2 were specifically set aside for code.org training that was conducted by our collaborator, Friday Institutes of North Carolina State University. Summer workshop topics included: diversity and inclusion in Computer Science; recruitment and retention of students; development of skills related to programming. 

Three weeks in summer 2022 (11 high school teacher participants, one high- school teacher coach, one high-school teacher lead code.org trainer)

 Four weeks in summer 2021 (9 high school teacher participants, one high- school teacher coach, one high-school teacher lead code.org trainer)

Saturday workshops:

 Four in 2021-2022

 Four in 2022-2023, including a reunion of both cohorts in March 2023

Creation of a NIC consisting of 21 high-school teacher participants and two lead code.org trainers)

Significant Results

Overall, CS4App appeared to be a successful program which met the goal of preparing teachers to teach the APCSP course. All of the respondents indicated that CS4App had:

  1. increased their understanding of recruiting challenges,
  2. increased their understanding of diversity, equity, and inclusion in computer science, and
  3. prepared them to teach computer science courses.

The culmination of the summer training program and the Saturday workshops seemed to increase the self-efficacy of the group with regard to teaching computer science.

 Despite the interruptions caused by the pandemic, teachers seemed to appreciate the community that was formed through this program and felt that it helped to bolster their content area and highlight the importance of computer science for their schools and districts.

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2024
Modified by: Rahman Tashakkori

Gain insight into the obstacles to computer      science (CS) education faced by the target population. 
Develop a comprehensive program to prepare      and support high school teachers to teach the APCSP course.

increased their understanding of recruiting      challenges,

Despite the interruptions caused by the pandemic, teachers seemed to appreciate the community that was formed through this program and felt that it helped to bolster their content area and highlight the importance of computer science for their schools and districts.
